data.title: The Albums of My Life – Part 3: 1980-1999
data.meta_description: Welcome to the third part of my four-part series where I share some of my favorite albums. This time around it's albums from 1980 to 1999.
data.text:
Welcome to the third part of my four-part series where I share some of my favorite albums. In case you missed the first two parts, which highlighted albums from 1950 to 1969 and 1970 to 1979, you can find them here:

The Albums of My Life – Part 1: 1950-1969

https://raspberriesmarvin.wordpress.com/2021/07/06/the-albums-of-my-life-part-1-1950-1960-2/

The Albums of My Life – Part 2: 1970s

https://raspberriesmarvin.wordpress.com/2022/06/03/the-albums-of-my-life-part-2-1970s/

For those of you who just joined, in the early days of my music listening and collecting, my tastes were pretty rigid: Pop, Rock, Soul/R&B. That was it. As the years passed, my tastes expanded, and I began to revisit music that in my youth would never have found its way onto my turntable.

With that in mind, let’s dive into the music from 1980 to 1999. Happy reading, and I hope you find something that piques your curiosity!

1980s

In the 1980s, record sales reached unprecedented heights, producing some of music’s most legendary artists and albums. During this decade, I became more discerning with my purchases and primarily focused on artists that I had been following for years, although a handful of new artists did manage to make it onto my list.

The albums are arranged chronologically based on their year of release.

1. Seconds Of Pleasure – Rockpile

Released 1980. Nick Lowe and Dave Edmunds, along with Billy Bremner and Terry Williams, brought their talents together to create a truly remarkable album, among the best of the past 40 years. The added bonus of the 45rpm that included Edmunds and Lowe’s covers of the Everly Brothers’ songs was delightful.

2. Tonite You’re Mine – Eric Carmen

Released 1980. On Carmen’s fourth solo release, ballads and rock songs combined nicely. The single “It Hurts Too Much” had all the necessary elements to become a big hit, but unfortunately, the song like the album went unnoticed.

3.Rave On – Artful Dodger

Released 1980. Here’s a recommendation for you: Artful Dodger, a band from Virginia, whose music was a perfect balance between Rock and Pop. Lead vocalist Billy Paliselli was one of the best.

4. Phil Seymour (1st Solo Album) – Phil Seymour

Released 1980. Seymour, who previously played drums in the Dwight Twilley Band, demonstrated his talent as a solo artist. Side 1, features exceptional Melodic Pop music, with the standout lead single “Precious To Me.”

5. Love Stinks – J Geils Band

Released 1980. Thanks to the title track, they finally started to get some traction on AM radio. Next year, would bring the blockbuster, ‘Freeze Frame.’

6. Voices – Hall & Oates

Released 1980. Thanks to the popularity of tracks like “Kiss On My List” and Paul Young’s successful cover of “Every Time You Go Away,” the duo were on their way to new popularity.

7. The River – Bruce Springsteen

Released 1980. After years of slowly building his audience, Springsteen finally reached the masses with his first Top 10 single “Hungry Heart.” It propelled the album to the top of the charts.

8. Mad Love – Linda Ronstadt

Released 1980. Linda embraced the New Wave genre with the lively single, “How Do I Make You.” She retained her status among the most beloved female singers.

9. Against the Wind – Bob Seger & the Silver Bullet Band

Released 1980. Seger’s regional stardom was surpassed with his most commercially-successful album. Included hit singles “Fire Lake” and the title track.

10. Hotter Than July – Stevie Wonder

Released 1980. Looking back on Stevie’s hit-filled catalogue, this release sometimes gets overlooked. If for nothing else but “Master Blaster,” it’s a worthwhile addition to his sterling credentials.

11. Heartland – Michael Stanley Band

Released 1980. Ohio has made a significant contribution to Heartland Rock, and one of its finest was the MSB. The track that stands out is “He Can’t Love You,” which became their first national Top 40 hit.

12. Glass Houses – Billy Joel

Released 1980. Joel’s career was on the rise after the success of his latest album, ‘The Stranger.’ His first release of the new decade was packed with chart-topping tracks including “It’s Still Rock And Roll To Me” and “You May Be Right.”

13. The Game – Queen

Released 1980. Moving farther away from their anthemic sounds of the 1970s, they delivered songs that were shorter in length, resulting in two blockbuster hits: “Another One Bites The Dust” and, “Crazy Little Thing Called Love.”

14. The Innocent Age – Dan Fogelberg

Released 1981. This album is impressive for maintaining focus throughout its four sides. The standout tracks include “Same Old Lang Syne,” “The Leader Of the Band,” and “Run For The Roses,” while “The Reach” is a showcase for its stunning beauty.

15. Mecca for Moderns – Manhattan Transfer

Released 1981. Despite not being known for producing hit singles, their cover of “The Boy From New York City” unexpectedly made it into the Top 10 Singles charts, leading to the Transfer being ‘discovered’ by new fans.

16. Dedication – Gary U.S. Bonds

Released 1981. With the assistance of loyal fans Steve Van Zandt and Bruce Springsteen, and backing from E Street and Southside Johnny’s band, Bonds made a powerful comeback with an outstanding collection including the hit single “This Little Girl.”

17. Face Value – Phil Collins

Released 1981. Collins’ remarkable debut album displayed few traces of Genesis and marked the beginning of a stellar solo career. “In The Air Tonight” has its own secure place in musical history.

18. Almost Blue – Elvis Costello

Released 1981. With the support of the Attractions, Elvis successfully ventures into the Country genre. Elvis’ unique vocal style adds authenticity to the songs.

19. 4 – Foreigner

Released 1981. After exploding onto the music scene four years earlier, they were starting to become an afterthought. Enter Mutt Lange’s influence, and a powerful sound emerged on tunes like “Jukebox Hero” and the hit single like “Urgent.”

20. Freeze Frame – J Geils Band

Released 1981. They were no longer a ‘best-kept secret.” “Centerfold” was the hit single they needed for their music to reach more ears.

21. El Rayo X – David Lindley

Released 1981. A talented multi-instrumentalist who was once Jackson Browne’s right-hand man decides to pursue his solo career. A delightful mix of Pop, Rock, Ska, and Reggae genres.

22. Fiyo On the Bayou – the Neville Brothers

Released 1981. The album marked the beginning of a successful run for the brothers. Wider popularity and radio airplay were just around the corner.

23. Private Eyes – Hall and Oates

Released 1981. The comeback was fully underway with the title track, as well as “I Can’t Go For That” which would both hit the top of the charts.

24. I Can’t Stand Still – Don Henley

Released 1982. Henley’s first solo album was a slow-building success thanks to the superb single, “Dirty Laundry“ The start of a career that set him apart from the Eagles.

25. Win This Record – David Lindley

Released 1982. Lindley’s second album offered a similar diverse range of sounds as his debut. Great tracks like “Brother John” and “Something’s Got A Hold On Me,” contributed to the musical gumbo.

26. Get Closer – Linda Ronstadt

Released 1982. A fantastic rendition of Ike & Tina’s “I Think It’s Gonna Work Out Fine,” featuring James Taylor was part of the collection. This marked her final album in the pop genre for some time, as her artistic direction would soon shift.

27. Hello I Must Be Going – Phil Collins

Released 1982. Following the phenomenal success of his debut ‘Face Value,’ Collins was firmly establishing himself as a solo artist. The first single was a fine cover of the Supremes’ “You Can’t Hurry Love.”

28. Tug Of War – Paul McCartney

Released 1982. This album showcases some of Macca’s best work since ‘Venus And Mars.’ Standout tracks were the touching tribute to John Lennon, “Here Today,” the upbeat “Ballroom Dancing,” and the title track.

29. Marshall Crenshaw (1st solo album) – Marshall Crenshaw

Released 1982. Crenshaw’s first album is a great blend of Pop, Rockabilly, and Country music. There is a melodic strength throughout. “Cynical Girl” remains a standout track even after all these years.

30. The Nylon Curtain – Billy Joel

Released 1982. The hit song was “Allentown,” but the Vietnam War story of “Goodnight Saigon” sets the tone for the entire album. An often-overlooked album in Joel’s collection.

31. Thriller – Michael Jackson

Released 1982. A game-changer in the music and video industry, and part of a trend that saw album sales reach new heights. It also broke a record by having the most Top 10 singles released from one album.

32. Men Without Women – Little Steven & the Disciples of Soul

Released 1982. Little Steven’s debut solo album continues the Soul-Rock sound he perfected with Southside Johnny.

33. IV – Toto

Released 1982. Despite steady radio airplay from Classic Rock stations, the band’s album sales were getting sluggish. ‘IV‘ reignited their career, garnering multiple Grammy awards. Four decades later, “Africa” has been resurrected.

34. Shoot Out the Lights – Richard and Linda Thompson

Released 1982. Brilliant music that soothes and aches emerge from the aftermath of a marriage breakup. Richard and Linda confront their demons.

35. The Nightfly – Donald Fagen

Released 1982. Fagen’s debut solo album is widely recognized as a high-quality musical listening experience. Featuring the same level of skill and creativity as his work with Steely Dan.

36. The Distance – Bob Seger & the Silver Bullet Band

Released 1982. Climbing to #5 on the Album charts, it was one of Seger’s strongest releases commercially and quality-wise. “Shame On the Moon” was a hit single, “Even Now” and “Making Thunderbirds” were classic Seger.

37. Colour By Numbers – Culture Club

Released 1983. To North American audiences, it appeared as if CC appeared out of nowhere. Soon everyone was discussing them. “Karma Chameleon” is still one of the catchiest tunes to have ever graced Top 40 radio.

38. War – U2

Released 1983. The album featuring “New Year’s Day” and “Sunday Bloody Sunday” played a crucial role in expanding the band’s popularity beyond their homeland and the UK.

39. Uh-Huh – John Cougar Mellencamp

Released 1983. The change in name signified a change in image, and this was also reflected in the shift in musical themes with “Pink Houses.”

40. An Innocent Man – Billy Joel

Released 1983. Billy’s homage to the music of his youth, covering a variety of styles ranging from The Four Seasons, James Brown, and Doo-Wop without sounding derivative. One of the most enjoyable albums in Joel’s collection.

41. How Will the Wolf Survive – Los Lobos

Released 1984. Many Top Albums playlists still feature the band’s initial major release. After 40 years, the messages in the title track and “A Matter Of Time” remain significant.

42. Home By Dawn – JD Souther

Released 1984. JD has built a career on his legacy as a songwriter. This album, didn’t attract the audience of his previous release, ‘You’re Only Lonely,’ however, there remains a high level of quality in the material.

43. Building the Perfect Beast – Don Henley

Released 1984. Henley’s second solo album is more structured than his debut. It includes some of his best tracks and his most incisive social commentary.

44. Born in The USA – Bruce Springsteen

Released 1984. The popularity of “Dancing In the Dark” drew in many new fans. From concert halls to arenas to stadiums, there was no looking back now.

45. Lights Out – Peter Wolf

Released 1984. He gained fame as the exceptional lead singer of the J Geils Band. With his debut solo album, he demonstrated that he had an array of talents that went beyond fronting a band.

46. Scarecrow – John Cougar Mellencamp

Released in 1985. One of the most significant albums of the 1980s, revealing a more serious side of Mellencamp that audiences had not seen before.

47. The Dream Of The Blue Turtles – Sting

Released 1985. Sting’s initial solo album tip-toed into the realm of jazz. It encompassed the single “If You Love Someone,” along with “Russians” and “Love Is the Seventh Wave,” showcasing Sting’s commercial side.

48. That’s Why I’m Here – James Taylor

Released 1985. The song “Only One” (featuring Don Henley and Joni Mitchell on background vocals) shines. James’ vocals throughout the album make this a truly enjoyable listening experience.

49. Songs from The Big Chair – Tears For Fears

Released 1985. Thanks to hits like “Shout,” “Head Over Heels,” and “Everybody Wants To Rule The World,” their second album became a global sensation.

50. Centerfield – John Fogerty

Released 1985. Hello again, John! Fogerty’s first album in nine years earned him a spot at the top of the music charts. “Centerfield” has become a staple at every baseball stadium.

51. Lives In the Balance – Jackson Browne

Released 1986. A showcase for his political side and the beginning of a series of similar-themed releases. The songs, including “Lawless Avenues” and “For America,” address universal issues.

52. Press To Play – Paul McCartney

Released 1986. It was an uneven album, but typical of Macca, the strong songs overshadowed the weaker cuts. Nice contributions from (10cc-ex) Eric Stewart.

53. Guitar Town – Steve Earle

Released 1986. Earle blew the Nashville audience out of their seats. A beautiful smorgasbord of Bluegrass, Honky Tonk, Folk, and Rock and Roll. The title song, as well as “Someday,” and “Fearless Heart” are standouts.

54. Graceland – Paul Simon

Released 1986. Political controversies aside, Simon opened eyes and ears to music styles they likely had never paid much attention to before. The musicianship is a highlight here.

55. Crowded House – Self-titled

Released 1986. Formed from the ashes of Split Enz, they were already popular in their native Australia and New Zealand before this debut. “Don’t Dream It’s Over” introduced them to audiences worldwide.

56. So – Peter Gabriel

Released 1986. Not even Gabriel could have guessed the new fans that would come aboard via the massive success of ‘So.’ Much of the credit must go to the hit single “Sledgehammer” and its ground-breaking video.

57. Robbie Robertson – Self-titled

Released 1987. A brilliant production by Daniel Lanois and a slew of memorable songs, including “Showdown At Big Sky” and “Fallen Angel.”

58. Bring The Family – John Hiatt

Released 1987. After years of being a ‘best kept secret,’ Hiatt finally makes the national charts. Songs that would endure: “Have A Little Faith In Me,” and “A Thing Called Love.”

59. The Joshua Tree – U2

Released 1987. Among the most ground-breaking bands of the 1980s. With their most commercially successful album, they proved that they could be topical, tuneful, and Top 40 all at the same time.

60. Very Greasy – David Lindley & El-Rayo X

Released 1987. Multi-instrumentalist Lindley’s third solo album. His knack for taking a familiar tune and turning it into something completely different and all his own is exemplified in his version of “Papa Was A Rolling Stone.”

61. Exit O – Steve Earle

Released 1987. Earle’s second album was just as solid as his debut ‘Guitar Town.’ Soon he’d explore other styles and work controversial themes into his music.

62. Tunnel Of Love – Bruce Springsteen

Released 1987. Just as he followed the huge success of ‘The River’ with the stark, low-key ‘Nebraska,’ he followed the mega ‘Born In the USA’ with this subtle release. Songs like “Brilliant Disguise” and “Two Faces” gave some insight into what was happening in his personal life.

63. Cloud Nine – George Harrison

Released 1987. The last album released in George’s lifetime. The hit single, “Got My Mind Set On You” brought him extensive radio airplay.

64. Copperhead Road – Steve Earle

Released 1988. Earle’s audience was growing steadily, and the title song solidified his status as a singer with something to say. Covering a variety of subjects and dipping into politics, he reached a turning point thematically.

65. Volume 1 – Travelling Wilburys

Released 1988. Who saw this coming? Given the talents within, the quality of the music shouldn’t have been a surprise. The lack of ego and the group camaraderie was a revelation. The music has lasted.

66. Rattle and Hum – U2

Released 1988. Following on the heels of the massive success of ‘The Joshua Tree,’ this live/studio album pushed the band to even greater heights. The singles “Desire” and “Angel Of Harlem” both hit the Top 10.

67. Tracy Chapman – Self-titled

Released 1988. Easily one of the finest debut albums in Pop music. Every song seemed to garner radio airplay, making Chapman a household name. An overwhelming commercial and critical success.

68. The End Of The Innocence – Don Henley

Released 1989. Henley’s third post-Eagles release became his most commercially successful. He hit a high note with the title track, “The Heart Of The Matter,” and others such as “Little Tin God” and “All She Wants to Do Is Dance.”

69. Oh, Yes I Can – David Crosby

Released 1989. The Croz’s second solo album, and first since 1971’s ‘If I Could Only Remember My Name’ was more about coming back into the world professionally and personally. It showed that he was still a vital singer/songwriter.

70. Flowers in The Dirt – Paul McCartney

Released 1989. Thanks to the help of Elvis Costello as co-writer on tunes such as “My Brave Face” and “You Want Her Too,” this collection ranks high on Macca’s solo list.

71. Yellow Moon – The Neville Brothers

Released 1989. A typically strong collection enhanced by Daniel Lanois’ production. “Sister Rosa” and the title track showcased a band in full flight.

72. Mystery Girl – Roy Orbison

Released 1989. The last album by Roy was released after his passing. It was a #5 hit on the Billboard Album Charts. The Bono-written track, “She’s A Mystery To Me,” is stunning vocally and musically.

73. Full Moon Fever – Tom Petty

Released 1989. Petty’s first solo album included members of the Heartbreakers, but more significantly, it included the musicians that would eventually lead to the formation of the Travelling Wilburys.

74. Steel Wheels – Rolling Stones

Released 1989. The band’s last album with original bassist Bill Wyman, launched a massive worldwide tour. It also consisted of some of their strongest original material in years.

75. Cry Like a Rainstorm, Howl Like the Wind – Linda Ronstadt

Released 1989. This album was recognized for Linda’s successful collaborations with Aaron Neville, particularly the chart-topping track “Don’t Know Much.”

76. March – Michael Penn

Released 1989. Despite not being able to replicate the success of this debut and the hit single “No Myth,” Penn is still a skilled songwriter and musician.

1990s

In the 1990s, popular music shifted towards dance-pop, while hip-hop emerged as a new favorite for radio airplay. The rise of ‘grunge‘ from Seattle also established itself as the new Rock genre. However, my list of albums does not include any of these trends.

1. The Neighborhood – Los Lobos

Released 1990. The troubadours from East LA remained musically head and shoulders above much of the competition. The title track continued to explore both their musical and hereditary roots.

2. Representing the Mambo – Little Feat

Released 1990. Even going through a variety of personnel changes, the level of musicianship has never wavered, and they’ve stayed true to their original sound.

3. I Fell In Love – Carlene Carter

Released 1990. Carter is the daughter of June Carter, and her rich heritage comes through in many of the songs here. This is country music as it used to be before it became homogenized.

4. Dear 23 – the Posies

Released 1990. From Seattle, but they got lost amongst the other bigger names and successes that came out of the city. Some spine-tingling Power Pop on tracks like “Suddenly Mary” and “Golden Blunders.”

5. Shooting Straight In the Dark – Mary Chapin Carpenter

Released 1990. The album gained popularity thanks to the success of the songs “Down At The Twist And Shout” and “Right Now.”

6. Pretty Blue World – Billy Falcon

Released 1991. He’s made a successful career co-writing with Bon Jovi. This solo release showed that even on his own, he had a knack for Pop/Rock.

7. Into The Great Wide Open – Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers

Released 1991. Back to the Heartbreakers fold after the solo ‘Full Moon Fever,’ no steps were lost. From the title track to ‘Learning To Fly’ and ‘Kings Highway,’ this is some of the band’s best material. Jeff Lynne helps again.

8. Better Days – Southside Johnny & the Asbury Jukes

Released 1991. With songwriting help from Little Steven and Springsteen, Southside returns to the sound that made him such a prominent figure on the Asbury Park scene in the 1970s. New songs that sounded like classics on the first listen.

9. Vagabond Heart – Rod Stewart

Released 1991. After a few underwhelming releases, Rod offered a solid effort that included popular singles such as “Rhythm Of My Heart” and “The Motown Song.”

10. New Moon Shine – James Taylor

Released 1991. One of JT’s most complete collections. “Shed a Little Light,” Copperline,” and “I’ve Got To Stop Thinkin’ Bout That” are some of the standout cuts.

11. Stax The Complete Singles 1959-1968 – Various

Released 1991. A gigantic collection of every single Stax single that mattered. A ‘must-have’ for all music fans.

12. Out Of TheCradle – Lindsey Buckingham

Released 1992. His third solo album saw Lindsey fine-tuning his sound and pushing farther away from Fleetwood Mac. Sonically perfect, Rock/Pop highlighted by expert playing.

13. Little Village – Little Village

Released 1992. For a short time in the early 1990s, this band got a lot of attention. It brought together Ry Cooder, John Hiatt, Nick Lowe, and Jim Keltner for a one-off that meshed Funk, Rock, Soul, and Country into a listening pleasure.

14. Duophonic – Charles & Eddie

Released 1992. The story goes that these NY’ers met on a subway, and one noticed that the other had a copy of Marvin Gaye’s ‘What’s Goin’ On’ album in hand. Their debut garnered two tasty radio hits, “Would I Lie to You” and “Love Is Beautiful Thing.”

15. Human Touch & 16. Lucky Town – Bruce Springsteen

Released 1992. Dual releases that were for the most part solo Springsteen. While they’ve become lost within Springsteen’s catalogue, each album contains some memorable tunes.

17. Hitsville U.S.A. 1959-1971 – Various

Released 1992. A brilliant collection of all the key Motown hits from its peak period. There’s nothing that you’d want that you won’t find here. Great liner notes as well.

18. Kiko – Los Lobos

Released 1992. Once again, the troubadours from East LA deliver. Their ability to consistently write strong, thoughtful material is impressive.

19. New Miserable Experience – Gin Blossoms

Released 1992. With cuts like “Hey Jealousy,” “Found Out About You,” and, “Allison Road,” there just wasn’t anything wrong with their second release.

20. Untitled – AJ Croce

Released 1993. AJ’s first release had a superb combination of Jazz/Blues-styled songs. Far from the sound of his dad, Jim, and clearly carving his own name.

21. Winter Light – Linda Ronstadt

Released 1993. A commercial disappointment, but massively accepted by critics. One of Linda’s strongest efforts, as she paid notice to underrated songwriters like Anna McGarrigle and Eric Kaz.

22. Off The Ground – Paul McCartney

Released 1993. A strong albeit unrecognized effort that was highlighted by “Hope Of Deliverance,” “Looking For Changes” and, “Peace In the Neighbourhood.”

23. Tuesday Night Music Club – Sheryl Crow

Released 1993. Crow’s debut was a highlight of the early 90s. “All I Wanna Do” was a chart-buster, but the album was loaded with stellar tracks.

24. Return To Pooh Corner – Kenny Loggins

Released 1994. It’s an album designed for children, filled with simplicity and beauty. Featuring contributions from Graham Nash, David Crosby, and Amy Grant.

25. August and Everything After – Counting Crows

Released 1994. The band’s debut sounded like a combination of early Springsteen, Dylan, and Van Morrison. Lead singer/songwriter Adam Duritz’s brilliance shines. The hit singles “Mr. Jones” and “Rain King” were highlights.

26. On the Floor of Heaven – The Blue Shadows

Released 1994. Led by Billy Cowsill and Jeffrey Hatcher, who were the primary singer-songwriters. Their music was characterized by a Country-Rock style that bore a resemblance to the sound of the Everly Brothers.

27. What A Crying Shame – the Mavericks

Released 1994. The strength of their third release is marked by the fact that many tunes are still in the band’s live repertoire 30 years later. The title track still resonates.

28. Big White Lies – Chris Von Sneidern

Released 1994. Thirty years ago, ‘Goldmine’ magazine picked this release as the all-time best Power-Pop album. High praise, but it has remained near the top of many lists.

29. Wildflowers – Tom Petty

Released 1994. One of the most important releases in Petty’s catalogue. This solidified his status as an artist who could succeed independently of his band.

30. Ain’t Had Enough Fun – Little Feat

Released 1995. With this release, the band introduced female vocalist Shaun Murphy into the fold. There was a slight change in their sound, but they continued with a funky and soulful style.

31. Thinkin’ About You – Trisha Yearwood

Released 1995. The title cut helped propel the album onto both the Pop and Country charts. Trisha’s talent for capturing Linda Ronstadt’s mood and feel set her apart as a unique vocalist.

32. Music For All Occasions – the Mavericks

Released 1995. The band continued to prove their versatility with hit singles like “Here Comes the Rain,” “All You Ever Do Is Bring Me Down,” “Missing You,” and their cover of “Somethin’ Stupid.”

33. Tonin‘ – Manhattan Transfer

Released 1995. The Transfer’s album of cover songs was arranged and performed with their own creative and distinct vocal and musical style. Who knew “Let’s Hang On” could work as a samba?

34. Sings the Hollies in Reverse – Various

Released 1995. A diverse collection of independent Power Pop musicians covering the works of the Hollies. A few of the tracks arguably surpassed the quality of the original versions.

35. Garage Demos Part 1 & 36. Garage Demos Part 2 – Venice

Released 1995. Two sets of brothers/cousins and siblings of the Lennon sisters. Their ability to harmonize ala CS&N, the Eagles, and the Beach Boys, caught my ear. These two releases collected some of their early work.

37. Feels Like Home – Linda Ronstadt

Released 1995. Linda returns to her country-rock sound with a collection that ranks among her best and also among her most underrated.

38. Bryndle – Self Titled

Released 1995. This album has no weak tracks. Considering the talent of the members – Wendy Waldman, Karla Bonoff, Andrew Gold, and Kenny Edwards – this came as no surprise.

39. Big Money Item – The Greenberry Woods

Released 1995. Chock-full of tasty tunes from a band that should have lasted longer. The jangle rings loudly!

40. Bringing Down the Horse – The Wallflowers

Released 1996. In the late 90s, their debut album dominated FM radio with its hit singles “6th Avenue Heartache” and “One Headlight.”

41. Fashion Nugget – Cake

Released 1996. Their second album, but the first to come to my ears, thanks to the cover of “I Will Survive,” “Daria,” and, “The Distance.”

42. All My Relations – the Neville Brothers

Released 1996. The Neville’s settle into a comfortable rhythm. Their focus remains on the spiritual message that runs throughout.

43. Sheryl Crow – Sheryl Crow

Released 1996. An excellent collection showcased by the hit singles “If It Makes You Happy” and “Everyday Is A Winding Road“. This was a worthy follow-up to “Tuesday Music Club.”

44. That Thing You Do – Various Artist’s Soundtrack

Released 1996. All original music captures the idealistic essence of 1960s Pop music.

45. High Lonesome Road – Vince Gill

Released 1996. This release climbed to the Top 5 on the Country charts and the Top 30 on the Pop charts. Includes the hit singles: “High Lonesome Sound,” “Worlds Apart,” “Pretty Little Adrianna,” “A Little More Love” and “You and You Alone.”

46. Marigold Sky – Hall & Oates

Released 1997. Although it did not achieve great commercial success, it is a remarkably strong release that even Darryl Hall ranks among the best from the duo.

47. Play On – Scott McCarl

Released 1997. McCarl served as the bassist and vocalist on the last Raspberries album ‘Starting Over‘. His solo album was a Power Pop delight.

48. Tremolo – Blue Rodeo |

Released 1997. They have had widespread recognition and admiration across Canada. “Falling Down Blue” and “It Could Happen To You” are among the standout tracks.

49. Destination Anywhere – Bon Jovi

Released 1997. Credit must be given to Bon Jovi for effectively stepping away from his band’s style. “Janey Don’t You Take Your Love To Town” remains a personal favorite.

50. Flaming Pie – Paul McCartney

Released 1997. There are several collaborations with Jeff Lynne, which is not a surprise considering it was recorded around the time of the Beatles Anthology project, where Lynne played a significant role. “Calico Skies” stands out.

51. Bitter Sweet – Kim Richey

Released 1997. A highly regarded songwriter. Tracks like “The Lonesome Side Of Town” and “Every River Runs Dry,” established her as a promising solo artist.

52. Born and Raised – Venice

Released 1997. The Lennon siblings/cousins adeptly captured the Folk-Country-Rock melodies of the bands from the early 1970s.

53. Kyle Vincent – Kyle Vincent

Released 1997. His first major label release featured outstanding Pop tracks such as “Arianne” and “Wake Me Up (When The World’s Worth Waking Up For).”

54. Some Other Sucker’s Parade – Del Amitri

Released 1997. “Not Where It’s At” and “Won’t Make It Better” are just two of the premier cuts from an album filled with ear candy.

55. Ask Anybody – Swirl 360

Released 1998. No one really knew who this band was or if they were even a band. The songs have touches of the Beatles and are Pop through and through. One particular track, “Hey Now,” garnered significant attention on AM radio.

56. Beg, Scream & Shout: The Big Ol’ Box of 60’s Soul – Various

Released 1998. Rhino brings back some stellar (and some forgotten) 1960s Soul music from Atlantic, Stax, and other smaller labels. An impeccable collection.

57. Have A Nice Decade / The 70’s Pop Culture Box – Various

Released 1998. Experience a blast from the 1970s with this collection of Pop, Rock, and Bubblegum hits. Rhino does a fantastic job of assembling these box sets that always include sparkling packaging.

58. Trampoline – the Mavericks

Released 1998. Add this to the long list of great albums by the Mavericks. Their fifth is memorable for songs like “Dance The Night Away” and “Fool #1.”

59. The Key – Vince Gill

Released 1998. A superb release highlighted by the single, “If You Ever Have Forever In Mind,” which is a timeless blend of Country and Pop music.

60. Global – Cowsills

Released 1998. The band that served as inspiration for the TV series “The Partridge Family” and gave us the hit songs “The Rain, The Park, And Other Things,” “Theme From Love American Style,” and “Hair.” Their musical comeback was solid. It deserved to see greater commercial success.

61. All In Time – Jim Cuddy

Released 1998. The co-leader of Blue Rodeo releases his first solo album. It’s got all the touches of his band but stays in a more folk-country vein.

62. Car Wheels on A Gravel Road – Lucinda Williams

Released 1998. Williams’ songs are carefully crafted. This release marked a significant turning point in her career, as it received widespread acclaim from critics and earned her a well-deserved Grammy Award.

63. Fools Parade – Peter Wolf

Released 1998. His fifth solo album continued a streak of high-quality material. Rolling Stone magazine praised it as one of the “essential recordings of the 1990s.“

64. Highways And HonkyTonks – Heather Myles

Released 1998. Heather was the opposite of other Country artists who were gravitating towards a more Pop-oriented sound. Her music remained true to the classic Country sound of the 60s and 70s, and her voice was a perfect match.

65. The Globe Sessions – Sheryl Crow

Released 1998. Sheryl releases her third superb album in just five years. Among female pop artists, she was a reigning force throughout the decade.

66. Wow & Flutter – Kyle Vincent

Released 1999. Featuring impressive tracks like “She’s Top 40” and “Jennifer.” His talent for creating infectious melodies and delivering them flawlessly is evident.

67. Echo – Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers

Released 1999. This album ranks as one of the band’s best works. The three singles, “Free Girl Now,” “Swingin‘,” and “Room at the Top,” are all exceptional examples of a band that continued to remain strong and active.
